characters: IN THE WAIST OF THE SHIP
IN THE LEE OF THE SHIP'S HULL, (TIME-LAPSE)
A HIGH POINT OF VIEW, TIME LAPSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack looks around the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have there, Stephen? He enters. Stephen has wired together the thorax of a bir skeleton and is suspending lead weights from it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The breastbone of a frigate bird. Do you remark its prodigious strength. Jack bends forwards into the candle-light, sharing his friends keen interest in this strange assembly

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do and I am not in the least surprised, for it reminds me of nothing so much as a ship under sail. See here the bowsprit. Here the mast, and here the backstays running aft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adds another weight) Ten pounds sixteen ounces. I am preparing a paper for the Royal Society. Jack straightens, moving with care between the bottled specimens, open books and brass measuring instruments

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking when our business here is finished, we will have to put in to Recife for provisions. You may care to take a tour round the forests of Brazil, botanizing and collecting specimens. An anaconda or two. A giant cassowary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should like it of all things, Jack. Thankyou.

dialogues.speaker: THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Time passes. The fog intensifies. White coils of mist dri and eddy over the glassy sea, RUN FINAL TITLES as the shi moves slowly through the night.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GREAT CABIN, LATER
dialogues.text: The chronometer ticks. The coffee-pot swings on its gimba JACK lies awake in his hanging cot. Finally he gives up trying to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killick! Killick there! Strong coffee, and light along my topcoat.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK on deck again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six bells and all's well. A hint of daylight to the east. The mist beginning to shi as an offshore breeze picks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 90 fathoms, white shelly sand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Four knots, Sir. BONDEN is still at the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oi reckon as she's liftin' Sir, if you feels like putting your Г©ad down. JACK takes his advice and goes below again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky a shade paler. A wind coming up.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE STARBOARD GANGWAY
dialogues.text: The lookout, VINCENT, peers into the mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Starboard gangway ahoy. HOLLOM, the oldest of the midshipmen, whose watch it now appears at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it, Vincent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard something. A bell. HOLLOM peers out into the fog, then turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Native fisherman perhaps. (shouts) Mr. Calamy! Midshipman CALAMY comes running forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The lead, if you please. Young CALAMY takes the lead, scrambles into the chains at bow of the ship and throws out the lead line. HOLLOM takes up a telescope and searches through the eddi of fog. Over HOLLOM's P.O.V. we can hear CALAMY sounding the dept

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sixty fathoms, white sand! Hollom folds his telescope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. It can't have been a reef marker. CALAMY, unconvinced, checks through his own telescope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: False alarm Mr CALAMY CALAMY ignores him, still scanning

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The telescope pans. A dark shape in the distance. The mis parts a little. A ship. Coming straight toward them. Close on CALAMY as he turns to camera, screaming -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enemy on the larboard bow! Beat to quarters!

dialogues.speaker: JACK'S SLEEP CABIN
dialogues.text: JACK instantly awake, piling out of his bed, still dresse

dialogues.speaker: BERTH-DECK
dialogues.text: A drum blazes as the off-duty watch tumble out of their hammocks and run to their battle stations.

dialogues.speaker: COCKPIT, ORLOP DECK
dialogues.text: Rows of wicked-looking instruments are hastily thrown on operating table by PADEEN, MATURIN's servant - saws, retractors and knives glistening in the lamp-light. DR. MATURIN hurries in blinking sleep out of his eyes as ties on his black apron - behind him, HIGGINS, the assist surgeon.

dialogues.speaker: POWDER MAGAZINE
dialogues.text: Little ADDISON and his team of powder-monkeys run with th boxes of gunpowder to the...

dialogues.speaker: GUN-DECK
dialogues.text: As LAMB, NAGEL and the other carpenters bash down cabin partitions, transforming the entire gun-deck into a singl continuous space, from the bows to the Captain's Great Ca in the stern. As the crews swarm about their guns, grotesque shadows ar thrown on the walls and ceiling by the numerous battle- lanterns arriving to illuminate the scene.

dialogues.speaker: WEATHER-DECK
dialogues.text: JACK and PULLINGS stride the length of the deck toward th bow [ ] . They pass crews manning the carronades while others swing the ship's small boats out and over the side be towed behind the ship.

dialogues.speaker: FORECASTLE
dialogues.text: JACK and PULLINGS join HOLLOM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where away? CALAMY points forward and a little to the left of the Surprise's bow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not two miles distant, Sir. JACK and PULLINGS stare through telescopes into the fog, which is beginning to lift. JACK lowers his telescope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Hollom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw nothing, nor heard anything either. Shall I ask them men to stand down? JACK steps closer to the bow, and again lifts his telesco

dialogues.speaker: TELESCOPE P.O.V
dialogues.text: A slow pan across the sea, past a darker patch of fog. Wh was that? The lens pans back toward the darker area to se series of flashes.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He turns and shouts to the crew -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lie down! Everybody lie down! His words are underscored by a series of distant explosio followed by a deep rumble, then a tearing, howling sound.

dialogues.speaker: THE SKY
dialogues.text: Chain shot and grape, bar and canister shriek through the air. A blizzard of iron.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE DECK
dialogues.text: The crew hit the deck, the last to drop is BONDEN hanging grimly to the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: MIDSHIPMAN BLAKENEY
dialogues.text: Close, as he tries to bury himself in the deck timbers.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: The broadside hits the bows and a cloud of splinters and metal scythes the length of the deck at head height. This rapidly followed by billowing smoke from a small fire now burning on the forecastle. CALAMY is working at putting the fire out as JACK issues stream of orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Run out the guns! Marines to the tops, and get that wounded man below! He pulls a gold watch from his pocket and checks the time

dialogues.speaker: 36A. GUN DECK
dialogues.text: Hollom is nervously supervising a gun crew which includes DAVIES and his mates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...C-cast loose now... Um swab. That's right. Run out your guns. The men work as a team, largely ignoring Hollom's hesitan instructions. The shot rack is empty

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shot. There's no shot!

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK, (CONTD)
dialogues.text: As red-coated marines led by Captain HOWARD climb into th rigging JACK calls to his clerk -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Note the time Mr. Watt. An anxious TOM PULLINGS appears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's out of our range, Sir! JACK calls to his sailing master, ALLEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closer, Mr. ALLEN. You must lay me alongside her at pistol-shot. ALLEN purses his lips. He knows what he's doing and sligh resents the instruction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pullings - bow-chasers to fire as she bears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's crossing their bows, about a mile distant.

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: PULLINGS is racing up the larboard gangway to the forecas past men stacking hammocks as blast protection.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE FORECASTLE
dialogues.text: Gun-captains stand ready, the slow-match burning in the t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire on the uproll. The little drummer's huge eyes are fixed on PULLINGS' fac The ship rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire! The drum-roll is all but drowned by the blast of the guns The smoke clears, the gunners look on baffled as their ba bounce harmlessly off the side of the enemy ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Greek) Witchcraft!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never seen the like of it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn and blast you! See to your guns! Fire high! Fire for the masts and rigging! As the enemy's murderous long guns run out again.

dialogues.speaker: THE ENEMY SHIP
dialogues.text: Her French ensign clearly visible as she swings broadside to the approaching Surprise - again her side lights up in series of red flashes.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: By the dim light of a battle-lantern STEPHEN struggles to hold a wounded man on the table, his feet slipping in poo of blood on the deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More sand on the floor, Mr. Higgins! The slightly hung-over HIGGINS reaches for the sand bucke and is thrown over by the awful jarring shock as the Acheron's third broadside hits home.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GREAT CABIN -
dialogues.text: The Captain's crockery smashes to the deck. KILLICK, curs freely, stows what he can.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE ORLOP
dialogues.text: Shards of timber implode, followed by a great spout of wa knocking the massive AWKWARD DAVIES sideways as he runs f the ladder carrying two cannon-balls. A second explosion, a second jet of water and DAVIES, fin his feet, starts yelling for the carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wood and Lead! Mr Nagel! Mr Lamb!!

dialogues.speaker: STAIRS
dialogues.text: Follow DAVIES as he runs up to the gun-deck with the shot under his arms past the powder-monkeys ADDISON and SWIFT, canisters of gun-powder slung over their shoulders, then sees MR. LAMB, the carpenter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orlop! We're holed! As LAMB dives for the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GUN-DECK
dialogues.text: DAVIES arrives to find a gaping hole opposite where his o gun once stood. Its crew lie scattered, horribly wounded dead. The dismounted gun and twelve pound shot are rolling arou dangerously. HOLLOM, the sole survivor, is backed against the bulkhead, cradling an injured arm. CALAMY emerges from the smoke, meets DAVIES's horror-stru gaze and takes command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Davies! Get those bodies overboard! (to HOLLOM) Mr. Hollom sir! HOLLOM sits immobilized by fear. CALAMY grabs the poulter JEMMY DUCKS, who has been rescuing the ship's goat, Aspas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jemmy - leave the damned goat and take Mr. Hollom below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, sir! The ship heels as she turns. Midshipman BLAKENEY, Calamy's rival in the game of marble turns to see the dismounted gun rolling free. He throws a hammock net under it, stopping its roll before it crushes CALAMY against the bulkhead. CALAMY shoots him a brief look of gratitude and runs aft. BLAKENEY carries on shouting to the powder-monkeys -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More shot! More cartridge!

dialogues.speaker: HULL OF THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: In the great jagged hole on the gun-deck where the gun wa destroyed, JACK stands framed, a wrathful soot-stained figure. He glances back at his men, hunched and ready, itching to fire. JACK (bellows)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steady... Wait for it!

dialogues.speaker: THE BATTLE
dialogues.text: to see the two ships about to pass abreast, the Surprise heading south as it were, the enemy ship, north. The French vessel is clearly the bigger ship, and from bo come the sounds of shouted orders and the thunder of drum They will pass broadside to broadside, 500 yards apart.

dialogues.speaker: GUN-DECK, SURPRISE
dialogues.text: JACK watching the enemy, judging the moment. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...wait WAIT! And FIRE! The great guns go off all together. The cannons leaping b between their crews. JACK snatches a powder-monkey, ADDIS out of the way of the lethal recoil.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: Smoke clears to reveal holes in the enemy's foretopsail, bowline hanging loose, but again many of her balls have failed to penetrate the enemy timbers. BONDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By all that's holy what is that ship made of? His question coincides with a third full broadside from t Frenchman. The Surprise's wheel shattered. BONDEN thrown aside, MR. WATT jerked back to the taffrail, the mizzenma hit. A rope sheers and JOE PLAICE is smacked on the skull by a swinging boom. Midshipman BLAKENEY, running up on deck, goes to help PLA and is struck down by a flying splinter - a shocking woun his upper right arm.

dialogues.speaker: COMPANIONWAY
dialogues.text: JACK is half-way up the ladder when he falls, scored acro the forehead by a musket-ball. Eyesight blurred. Hearing gone. He is dimly aware of smal arms cracking above his head, and someone trying to lift JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belay there ye poxed son of a whore! MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must go below, Sir, you must let me help you below! JACK puts a hand to his bleeding forehead and drags himse back up the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE TOPS
dialogues.text: A furious exchange of fire between CAPTAIN HOWARD's marin and the sharpshooters in the enemy's rigging. Howard, a big red-faced man, is in his element, laughing madly every time he scores a hit.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK emerges into bloody chaos: screams of the wounded al around, the enemy ship moving astern in mist and gun-smok He wipes blood from his eye as he raises his telescope. 54/55.   TELESCOPE P.O.V. As the ship passes, her name is visible on the transom - Acheron. PULLINGS V.O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir.... Jack lowers his telescope. Pullings' expression spells catastrophe PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the rudder.

dialogues.speaker: STERN OF THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Grim-faced, JACK hobbles to the shattered taff-rail, sees BONDEN soaked, having climbed down onto the stern-post. BONDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts up) It's shot away below the waterline!

dialogues.speaker: COCKPIT
dialogues.text: STEPHEN, up to his armpits in blood, operating on a wound man, looks up to see three more seriously injured men arriving. He pauses, aware of some change. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we not firing?

dialogues.speaker: GUN-DECK
dialogues.text: Spirals of drifting smoke. Blackened bleeding men, their pointing at nothing FASTER DOUDLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No steerage. NEHEMIAH SLADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're fish in a barrel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fog has rolled back, like a great curtain, to reveal two frigates. The badly damaged Surprise, drifting rudderless. The Acheron, most of her sails intact, beginning the turn which will put her in position to finish off the Surprise

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK is joined by ALLEN as the enemy vessel starts crossi their wake. ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's coming about, Sir. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I strike the colours? All eyes on Jack, poised on the brink of awful defeat. ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid there's nothing else for it. JACK looks from the wall of fog to the three little boats they are towing astern. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned if there ain't. We'll tow her.

dialogues.speaker: STERN OF THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Sudden feverish activity, running and shouting as men scramble down into the boats. DAVIES settles himself besi NAGEL in the cutter, turning to look at the approaching Acheron. His P.O.V.: puffs of smoke from its bow-chasers. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sail trimmers away, Warley, make what sail you can! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stern-chasers to fire when she's in range!

dialogues.speaker: STERN OF SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Gouts of water from the enemy gunfire rise not fifty yard from them, acting as little needed encouragement for the boats to get clear of the stern and pull around towards t bows as....

dialogues.speaker: MAINMAST/FOREMAST
dialogues.text: Men scramble up the ratlines, and through the shattered rigging.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: Two long brass nine-pounders set up through the open wind of the Captain's day cabin, open fire on the approaching Acheron. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fire!

dialogues.speaker: 65A. MAINMAST
dialogues.text: WARLEY, captain of the maintop, directs his men about the mare's nest of rigging, getting a tattered top-sail to fi with what little breeze there is. WARLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sharp now with that fancy-line! To the clew line from the reef points, Cully, double up and run her back again!

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: Through PULLINGS' telescope: the enemy ship coming straig at them, her guns now getting the range of the Surprise. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's gaining on us. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start the water, carronades over the side.

dialogues.speaker: THE QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: Crewmen furiously at work cutting the ropes securing the on the quarterdeck.

dialogues.speaker: THE STERN
dialogues.text: Water spouts from the pumps, while at the same time the quarterdeck guns tumble into the ocean. (NOTE: they only abandon guns on the quarterdeck, not the main armament on the gun-deck.)

dialogues.speaker: FORECASTLE
dialogues.text: JACK races to the bows. Towlines strain as the three smal boats pull the great ship toward the curtain of fog and cloud. He yells to the straining oarsmen - JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull! Pull for your lives.

dialogues.speaker: THE BOATS
dialogues.text: The men heave on their oars, faces bathed in sweat, the towlines taut behind them, dragging the Surprise toward t safety of the fog-bank.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: to see the Surprise slipping into the cover of fog and lo cloud, only her top masts visible, before they too disapp

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK joins his officers looking back into the white-out, the direction of the enemy. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet now. No calls, no shouts. Mr. ALLEN, signal the men in the boats to head due east. ALLEN hurries toward the bows, as behind them the fog is momentarily illuminated by flashes of gunfire from their pursuer.

dialogues.speaker: THE LEADING JOLLY BOAT
dialogues.text: CALAMY, in the prow of the jolly-boat, sees ALLEN on the ship, signalling the turn to eastward. CALAMY signals to BONDEN in the stern of the jolly-boat. BONDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (urgent whisper) Starboard haul. And stroke! Stroke! One side stops rowing and the boat turns.

dialogues.speaker: THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: A low angle, the ship coming slowly toward us. Beyond, the rowers strain at their oars, the great ship rearing out of the mist above them, as though carried on their backs.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK OF THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Somewhere astern and to the left JACK can hear shouting o the Acheron. Flashes of cannon fire, directed away from t PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's beating inshore. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep rowing

dialogues.speaker: MASTS OF THE SURPRISE,, (TIMELAPSE)
dialogues.text: The tortured sounds of exhausted men rowing as skeins of drift away to reveal a dim, yellow moon. On the horizon t battered ship in silhouette, lines stretching ahead to he three small boats.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK OF THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Some of the wreckage has been cleared aside, the wounded moved below. We can hear their moans, and the constant creaking of the bilge pumps. JACK and his officers scan the moonlit sea through telescopes. JACK's telescope POV: A long slow pan along the dark hori ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe we've lost her, Sir. JACK collapses his telescope. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pass the word to ship oars 78 IN THE JOLLY BOATs. - NIGHT The rowers slump forwards in their seats, their hands raw crabbed.

dialogues.speaker: STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: JACK moves down a ladder past LAMB coming up from below, soaking wet and exhausted with his mate Nagel. LAMB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three feet of water in the hold, Sir, but the pumps are keeping it from gaining. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very good, Mr. Lamb. The constant creaking and sloshing of the pumps becomes louder as he continues down past men handing up food and powder from the flooded levels below.

dialogues.speaker: SICK-BAY
dialogues.text: Stephen, his face spattered with blood, is adjusting the of a lantern when Jack arrives beside him JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) What's the butchers bill? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six dead, thirteen wounded. He notices the gash on Jack's forehead Your head ... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Brushes him away) Later. STEPHEN raises his lantern to reveal groaning bloodstaine men close-packed in the gloom. Together they make the rounds, passing men propped uprigh their mates, pale with shock or tense with pain, some struggling to breathe, some barely alive. JACK clasps hands, whispers encouragement. A bandaged head swims into the glow of the lamp, streaked with blood and deeply unconscious. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this - Joe Plaice? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sotto) A severe depressed fracture of the skull. I am not sure he will see out the night. Moving on to another barely recognizable face: young Blakeney, pale and sweaty, breathing hard from the pain a the blood loss. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Blakeney? BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just a broken arm, Sir. JACK looks at STEPHEN, whose expression is grim, but he s nothing, steering Jack forward to the foot of the ladder where they can speak more privately STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will do everything possible. I know you were close to his father. Jack nods, defeat weighing heavily, and makes to go. Step puts a restraining hand on his shoulder. STEPHEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One moment Jack let me look at that brow of yours. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its a scratch. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will tell you if its a scratch or not. Sit down. Jack submits meekly, and sits on a lower rung while Steph puts a bandage round his forehead JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did he find us Stephen? Seven weeks sailing and he happened in darkness on our exact position. Its uncanny. He really is a phantom STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless she was alerted to our presence, and looking for us. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tosh. How could that be? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French have their spies, in Britain as elsewhere. JACK (astonished)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying there are traitors in the Admiralty? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am saying do not imagine it was a lone privateer who did this to us. He is working for Napoleon himself, with access to all that tyrant commands, overtly and covertly. So do not let defeat weigh too heavily upon you.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: Wan dawn light reflects off the ceiling onto the bloody, bandaged officers, conducting an angry post-mortem as KIL serves coffee. ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Call her a frigate? Ha! You ask me she's no more a frigate than a painted Dutchman. More like a ship of the line, a two-decker more'n a frigate. MOWETT is trying to staunch a persistent nosebleed. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One does wonder what manner of hull she has. Our balls seemed to bounce right off her. Jack enters, his head newly bandaged. He walks past the seated officers and stands looking out through the stern windows. The officers continue their conversation, though their words are intended for Jack PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had the weather-gauge and long eighteens which could hit us beyond our effective range. That's the sum of it ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And   40 guns to our 28, I counted the muzzle flashes. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was an unfair match, no dishonor in defeat no dishonor at all. Jack still has his back to them. He puts his hand in his pocket and finds something there - the shattered fragment his gold pocket watch. ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs) Well, we can patch up our main and mizzen the foresail is too far gone so we'll bend our spare. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir. Jack finally turns. PULLINGS (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Allen is confident, with basic repairs, we can get home as we are... allowing for a stop in Jamaica. ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Port Royal we can haul her into dry- dock, and hopefully get her home without... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not going home. An expectant hush. KILLICK is all ears, as he picks up th coffee cups and places them carefully on a silver tray. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is our purpose here gentlemen? Why were we sent? To punish a blackguard privateer who has decimated our Atlantic whaling fleet and now threatens to do the same in the pacific. Are we to leave those ships to his mercy and slink back into Portsmouth - another defeat to add to the list. Is that what we draw our wages for? I say we pursue her and pay her back with interest ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respect, Captain, she could be half- way to Cape Horn by the time we're repaired and underway. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sternly) Then there's not a moment to lose.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: KILLICK exits the cabin with the tray of coffee cups. As passes them to his mate, BLACK BILL - KILLICK (a whisper)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're for the Horn.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGHOUT THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Word passes like lightning from the wounded in the orlop, the beak of the ship MUTTERED VOICES AD LIB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -   The Horn you say? -   Never! In this condition? -   Eh? What news mates -   Heading for where?!

dialogues.speaker: FORECASTLE
dialogues.text: A few of the old 'Surprises' have gathered for a smoke, a of them men who've sailed with JACK before: Jittery alcoh Higgins, loyal Nehemiah Slade, sharp-faced tobacco-chewin Faster Doudle, and the big Welshman Awkward Davies, still shaken by the loss of his gun-crew. higgins

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're for hell in a hand-barrow if you ask my opinion slade

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm game. If the captain says we can take her we can take her. DAVIES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we catch her is the question. And if we do what's different? She'll just hold us off with them long eighteens til she sends us all to the bottom. All for what? DOUDLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you for what, matey. She's a privateer, loaded with all the gems of Araby. Think of the gold. Think of the prize-money. HOLLAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoi there! You men jump to it!

dialogues.speaker: WAIST OF THE SHIP
dialogues.text: The gratings are hauled aside and light floods down into gun-deck.

dialogues.speaker: GUN-DECK
dialogues.text: Part of a huge tree-trunk - spare timber for repairs - is manhandled by a dozen crewmen. HOLLAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heave. And heave. Handsomely now. One long pull. Belay!

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: Crewmen labour at the capstan. HOLLAR (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two six heave! Two six heave! The huge log rises from below and hangs suspended from it gantry. JACK shouts down from the quarterdeck - JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have her placed along the gunwale for now, Mr. Hollar, and the guns moved to that side also.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE JACK'S HEAD
dialogues.text: Men are hanging in the rigging throwing down damaged sect of rope. FASTER DOUDLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All clear below!

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK dodges the falling rope, moving back, past NAGEL and men who are cutting out damaged sections of the gunwale w saws and adzes, prizing up decking and wrestling with the wrecked steering mechanism.

dialogues.speaker: THE STERN
dialogues.text: JACK looks down to where PULLINGS and others have lifted broken rudder from its hinges.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The ship swarming with men, cutting, splicing, hammering hauling. Every able-bodied soul hard at work.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: An optimistic breeze has picked up, fluttering the tatter ensign. The deck is now sloping at a forty-five degree angle. KIL hands a sandwich to Pullings who passes it down to JACK. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn this wind, Mr. Pullings! The Acheron will be making a hundred and fifty miles a day in this. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, but hugging the coast, and stopping to board the odd merchantman JACK smiles at this and bites into his sandwich. To the uphill side, carpenters are erecting a scaffolding over the side of the ship.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP
dialogues.text: The ship's copper-plated keel is partly revealed as the m clamber and slip about on the steeply-sloping side erecti scaffolding. The tropical heat resounds with shouts, curs and hammering.

dialogues.speaker: SIDE OF THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Carpenters working inside the scaffolding, are fitting ne sections of wood into the holes low in her hull. LAMB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Down. Down. Stop. The new piece of wood is an almost perfect fit. MR. LAMB marks the places where it is jamming. LAMB (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up again. Then he begins to work on it with his rasp.

dialogues.speaker: DUSK
dialogues.text: Among tropical fish, a diver, a Greek crewman, 'OLD SPONGE' (father of YOUNG SPONGE) a hammer at his belt, pl a few smaller holes with hemp fibre, then surfaces to...

dialogues.speaker: THE SIDE OF THE CUTTER
dialogues.text: OLD SPONGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (In Greek) The smaller bit. No. That bit there. YOUNG SPONGE passes him a piece of lead and some nails an OLD SPONGE dives again. Our P.O.V. descending into the sea as...

dialogues.speaker: WAIST OF THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Roaring flames, flying sparks, the clang of metal on meta forge has been set up. Powder-monkeys sweat on the bellow The ship's blacksmith is churning out iron bolts, pintles gudgeons, which are snatched away by NAGEL with tongs and thrown into a bucket of water to cool. A few yards away, wood chips fly from LAMB's adze as the ship's massive new stern post takes shape. The new rudder is laid out flat, already cut to its final shape and being strengthened with great nails and iron ba which NEHEMIAH SLADE and AWKWARD DAVIES are nailing into place. The hammering travels through the ship to...

dialogues.speaker: THE SICK BERTH
dialogues.text: BLAKENEY with his splinted arm jerks awake, feverish and confused. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. Not through my nose! CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Its alright. William. You were dreaming. Blakeney looks around, disoriented and finds Calamy by hi side. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Joe Plaice told me when you die they sew you up in your hammock with the last stitch through your nose... to make sure you're not just sleeping CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know old Joe, always telling [ ] stories. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true though? [    ] About the last stitch? CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, you'll be stitching me in mine first. BLAKENEY (drifting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not through my nose. You'll tell them. CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nods) Nor any other part of you. Trying to make light of it, though he fears BLAKENEY is dying.

dialogues.speaker: SICK BAY, LATER
dialogues.text: CALAMY has fallen asleep by BLAKENEY's side. He wakes to STEPHEN sniffing BLAKENEY's wound. CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it mending, sir? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm afraid it will not do.

dialogues.speaker: THE COCKPIT
dialogues.text: BLAKENEY is lowered onto the table, delirious. CALAMY hol his head and PADEEN, MATURIN's giant manservant, his legs which are lashed together. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Mamma. Mamma. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the laudanum speaking. You will be a regular Nelson. He tests the edge of his knife with his thumb. CALAMY places the leather gag between BLAKENEY's teeth. Padeen mumbles a Gaelic prayer. STEPHEN turns and grips BLAKENEY shattered arm. A sharp, grating noise as STEPHEN works out of shot, cutt off the arm. Close on STEPHEN, lips compressed, utterly focussed. He puts down the bloody knife and reaches for the spatula the pail of hot tar. BLAKENEY has not uttered a sound, though he is shaking uncontrollably and his face is wet with tears. CALAMY has tears in his eyes also. STEPHEN finishes his work, breathing hard, a gentle smile BLAKENEY. STEPHEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There. I have never seen a braver patient.

dialogues.speaker: SICK-BERTH
dialogues.text: An exhausted CALAMY keeps vigil by BLAKENEY's cot. The bo wakes, and looks for CALAMY in the darkness. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peter? Is that you? I dreamed they cut my arm off. Then he realizes, with sudden horror, that it wasn't a dr CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You would have died else. Blakeneys eyes brim with tears and he turns away CALAMY (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come. You can still sup your grog with your left. And I shall take your turn at marbles.

dialogues.speaker: MIZZEN TOPGALLANT
dialogues.text: MOWETT stands in the cross-trees, making a final check on lashings round the new mizzen top. Below him the great wo is nearing completion, men swarming like ants over every of the hull. MOWETT climbs down past FASTER DOUDLE who has one leg loo through the shrouds and is splicing a rope with both hand and his teeth. Farther down, a patched sail is being furled up tight in gaskets. Beyond that, at the base of the main-mast a fascinated gr of men have gathered to watch the Doctor trepanning JOE PLAICE.

dialogues.speaker: BASE OF THE MAINMAST
dialogues.text: STEPHEN's drill carves out a neat disc of bone to reveal purplish mass which he starts spooning from the cavity. A small crowd of crewmen pause in their work, watching th doctor with morbid fascination as he drops the purple stu in a dish. SLADE (shouts)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is them his brains, Doctor? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that is just blood. These are his brains. Exposing them to view. Several of the crew move in for a closer look. The armourer hands STEPHEN a flattened coin, which he begins to screw in place over the cavity as the hands whisper his praises to the men who have never seen Stephen at work. SLADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Physician he is, not one of your common surgeons. FASTER DOUDLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cured Prince Billy of the marthambles and the strong fives, wouldn't look at you for under ten guineas on land. DAVIES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [   ] Knows his birds and beasts too boyo, show him a beetle and he'll tell you what it's thinking.

dialogues.speaker: THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: A wind causes the ship to turn on its moorings, stirring impatiently, like a racehorse ready to be off as...

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: ...JACK jumps down from the mizzen ratlines. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let us be off, Mr. Allen! ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weigh anchor! All hands to make sail. Mr Hollom!

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: Barefoot men are suddenly running to their stations, raci above and below, running out along the bowsprit, up the ratlines, along the yards. A small group, supposed to be assisting Hollom, are contrasting slow off the mark HOLLOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bear a hand there you fellows! The men he is addressing, shoot him a look of distaste wh unsettles Hollom slightly, then they assist him pulling o rope

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up and down Sir, thick and dry for weighing.

dialogues.speaker: WAIST OF THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Men strain on the capstan bars.

dialogues.speaker: BOWS
dialogues.text: The anchor bursting up out of the sea.

dialogues.speaker: MASTS OF THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: The shrouds darken with climbing figures, framed against sun. HOLLAR (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trice up. Lay out. Sheet home! Hoist away!

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: HOLLAR staring up as the sails unfurl and fill with wind. HOLLAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheerly there in the foretop, our William! T'garnsl sheets! Hands to the braces! Men slide down ropes from high amongst the shrouds, then swing out and drop down to the deck like monkeys, pulling ropes and sails tight with the weight of their bodies.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The ship spreading its wings. A sudden cracking of canvas she turns and runs directly downwind.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: The sun has sunk lower. BONDEN, solid as the rock of Gibraltar is back at the helm, the wind stronger and dire behind. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speed, Mr. Boyle BOYLE heaves the log clear of the ship's side. The log li races out on its reel. BOYLE checks the run, pulls the pi BOYLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ten and a half knots, Sir. JACK makes no comment but the news seems to please him.

dialogues.speaker: THE WATER
dialogues.text: The great hull powers past us.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: KILLICK prepares toasted cheese in his small serving-area From inside the cabin, the sound of a violin and a cello tuning up. KILLICK glances irritably at the door and elbo his mate, BLACK BILL. KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here we go again: scrape, scrape, screech, screech and never a tune you could dance to, not if you were drunk as Davey's sow.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: JACK and STEPHEN are both keen amateur musicians - JACK, violin, STEPHEN cello. As Stephen completes his tuning, Jack experiments with a refrain. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that one I know, or are we breaking new ground? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am trying to remember that air they played all those years ago at the Governors house in Port Mahon. You remember When we first met. Corelli if I'm not mistaken. He plays another riff STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that is your "A" you are very much so. This is A. Jack corrects his A string, plays another few bars JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Locatelli. pom pom pom pom STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I remember is you being unable to sit in your seat the entire performance. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye and you practising apon that poor bishop with your "puddings athwart the starboard Gumbrils" or some such arrant nonsense. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (laughs) No. That was off Toulon, during the blockade. At our first meeting they played this: He plays a short refrain JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. Entirely off the mark.   pom-pom- POM I have now He plays another variation STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (enjoying the game) Or was it something like this.... Cello answers violin, as they hand it back and forth, improvising freely now with an infinity of variations, sometimes playing together, sometimes separately, suddenl hitting it, the music soaring and continuing over

dialogues.speaker: A HIGH POINT OF VIEW, TIME LAPSE
dialogues.text: The tiny ship on the vastness of the ocean. From its side cotton-wool puffs of smoke.

dialogues.speaker: GUN-DECK
dialogues.text: A rippling broadside, the crews sweating over their guns. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And pitch 'em up! It's spars and rigging we want! MOWETT timing the gap between each broadside. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three minutes ten, Sir. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good enough! We must fire three broadsides to her two. Again! Turning to BLAKENEY, who though much recovered, still loo pale and a little unsure of himself. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Blakeney? Think you can supervise a gun? BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you will. Sir. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Spitfire', hop to it. BLAKENEY takes command of the gun. To one side CALAMY is charge of 'Beelzebub', on the other side HOLLOM is now directing 'Sudden Death'. Once again the orders are given, and the crews, now compe with each other, go through the sequence: 'Out Tompions', 'Cast loose your guns', 'Cartridge. Ball. Prime. Run out gun. Prime. Aim. Stand clear... Fire!!'

dialogues.speaker: AND AGAIN
dialogues.text: As another broadside shakes the deck, STEPHEN hauls his collecting net on board and empties out a glistening arra sea creatures - shrimps, squid and minnows, glinting like opals in the pink light. MOWETT (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes five, Sir. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again!

dialogues.speaker: AND AGAIN
dialogues.text: It's a race. JACK's orders are just a formality, the sequ having become so automatic now. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out Tompions... Run out your guns... Prime. Seconds ticking away on MOWETT's stopwatch, barrels float the sea a hundred yards out. JACK (CONT.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she bears, from forward aft. Point your guns... Fire!!

dialogues.speaker: THE OCEAN AT NIGHT
dialogues.text: The black ship spouting tongues of flame, the water aroun the target barrels erupting in great spouts. MOWETT (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two minutes dead.

dialogues.speaker: THE GUNPOWDER ROOM
dialogues.text: Boom! Another splendidly coordinated broadside resounds through the ship as the powder-monkeys come racing down through the dreadnought screens to the magazine and back more cartridge. For them too it's a race, little ADDISON just ahead of SW RYE hot on his heels.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN'S CABIN
dialogues.text: The sound of the guns is faint down here, at least when h from STEPHEN's perspective - his ears are stuffed with wa He is surrounded by his specimen bottles, and he looks fr his microscope to his ledger where he is documenting the array of aquatic life-forms. He removes his ear-plugs, bu the noise of the guns is deafening and he hastily replace them.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GUN-DECK
dialogues.text: MOWETT watches the second hand of his stopwatch, glancing as he notes - The concentrated fury of the men swabbing, ramming, heavi in, heaving out, firing at a raft this time. And he stops the watch as the first gun fires. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One minute forty-nine, Sir! His voice is drowned by the firing of the other guns in c succession entirely demolishing the raft, the sound mixin with cheering and the frenzied hammering of Nagel and his mates as the gun-deck partitions are cheerfully re-erecte

dialogues.speaker: IN THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: The table is dragged back into place and settings laid fo dinner. JACK enters, his face flushed with victory. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killick? Killick there. KILLICK appears. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have for us tonight? KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which it's, Soused Hoggs-Face. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aah! My favorite.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN DECK
dialogues.text: The sky a great canopy of stars, the ship racing onwards through the warm night. Crew men and the recovering wounded have come up on deck. they sit around in groups, supping their grog. Someone produces a jaw-harp, someone else a drum. A guitar is passed from hand to hand, stopping with BLACK BILL who sings a ballad in an African dialect. There's an effortless integration of race and rank, of ag and nationality - bonds forged by battle and hardship. OLD SPONGE gets up and dances a Greek dance: obviously a favorite among the crew. Cheering and cat-calls. Lanterns coming up from below. More dancing, insults in many languages, and a song. GUN-CREWS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boneparte Boneparte That red-faced son of an old French fart Hey ho, stamp and go Stamp and go, stamp and go Hey ho, stamp and go

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: The singing mixes with the end of a lively dinner given b JACK for his officers, including a special guest, young BLAKENEY. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your permission, Sir, Mr. Mowett has composed a short poem in honour of our mission. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hear it, Mr. Mowett. Reactions around the table, glasses re-filled in anticipation. MOWETT stands and declaims with a number of precise airy gestures, like a conductor. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our brotherhood, some old, some new. In blood baptized, in strength renewed. In purpose unified and true. All thoughts of home forsaken. Where duty leads us, there we go. Nor rest nor comfort shall we know. Until the unrepentant foe, is boarded sunk or taken ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising their glasses) Aye! Capital! Well said! Hear him, hear him! 'Sunk or taken'... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye and when we do take her we shall give her to Tom Pullings as his first command. If he don't die before then. Bumpers up Tom ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (A toast) 'To wives and sweethearts'. They raise their glasses - ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'To wives and sweethearts'. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And may they never meet. Amid the laughter someone bumps Blakeney's stump. He winc then puts a brave face on it BLAKENEY (to JACK)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I believe you knew Nelson, Sir? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Nelson? Yes. I had the honour of serving under him at the Nile. (aside) Mr. Mowett, the bottle stands by you, sir. (as the bottle moves on) In fact I dined with him twice, and he spoke to me on both occasions. The table goes quiet. BLAKENEY is wide-eyed, though partl from his strenuous efforts to appear sober. JACK (CONT.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first time he said to me - 'May I trouble you for the salt, sir?' I have always tried to say it as close as I could [   ] The second time someone had offered him a boat-cloak on a cold night and he said no, he was quite warm - his zeal for his king and country kept him warm. Amid the general agreement - 'Hear him, hear him', etc. STEPHEN is noticeably silent. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sounds absurd, I know, and were it another man you would cry out, "Oh, what pitiful stuff" and dismiss it as mere enthusiasm, but with him you felt your heart glow. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his glass) To Lord Nelson. ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord Nelson! [ ] Stephen joins on the toast, but JACK knows that his friend deplores such overt patriotism and seeks to draw h back in with a joke. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see those two weevils, Doctor? He points at a faint movement amongst the crumbs of a shi biscuit. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which would you choose? The table tenses with anticipation of one of the Captain' 'jokes'. STEPHEN concentrates. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is not a scrap of difference. They are the same species of curculio. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But suppose you had to choose? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I would choose the right-hand weevil, it has a perceptible advantage in both length and breadth. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There I have you. You are completely dished. Don't you know in the Navy you must always choose 'the lesser of two weevils'? He thunders with laughter, the rest joining in, breathles with mirth, tears of laughter streaming down their faces ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Pon my life. He who would pun would pick a pocket. DГЅe not smoke it doctor? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (poker faced) Sure there would be some poor thin barren minds that would catch at such a paltry clench. Then he too cracks a smile and joins in their laughter

dialogues.speaker: MAIN DECK
dialogues.text: The crew continue with their own celebration. The excitement penetrates JOE PLAICE's stupor. Never havi woken since the trepanning he suddenly opens his eyes and speaks. PLAICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "...And the righteous shall inherit the earth." The men around him stare in amazement. BONDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You hear that. He said something. Joe spoke! Say something else Joe JOE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Handy with that gasket BONDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouts up to the quarterdeck) He spoke doctor. Joe plaice spoke

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: The officers have appeared on deck with their coffee and Stephen raises a hand in acknowledgment.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE RIGGING
dialogues.text: Midshipmen CALAMY RYE and BOYLE are eating from a bag of broken biscuits ('ships nuts') as they sit perched up in rigging. On seeing JACK, they break into their own song. MIDSHIPMEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our captain was very good to us. He dipped his prick in phosphorus. It shed a light all through the night. And steered us through the Bosphorus.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK pretends not to have heard, but he can't hide his sm Beside him in a chair sits BLAKENEY, his empty jacket sle pinned to his front 'Nelson' style, laughing incredulousl the older boys cheek. From somewhere on the forecastle, WARLEY and his top-men start singing. TOP-MEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farewell and adieu you fine Spanish ladies Farewell and adieu to you ladies of Spain... The older midshipman, HOLLOM joins in, his fine voice soa effortlessly over the others, hijacking their roistering ballad and converting it to something much more poignant. HOLLOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For we've received orders to sail for Old England. Perhaps we shall never more see you again His singing is appreciated by STEPHEN on the quarterdeck. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a wonderfully true voice Mr. Hollom does possess.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE WAIST
dialogues.text: KILLICK and NAGEL are less than impressed with HOLLOM and sing over him, led by ORRAGE the cook. ORRAGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come all you thoughtless young men, A warning take by me, And never leave your happy homes to sail the raging sea.

dialogues.speaker: OCEAN
dialogues.text: The Surprise sailing away from us, the chorus drifting ac the darkness. 135a.   OCEAN. DAY The colours are changing, from the rich hues of the tropi to the cold muted colours of colder, more southerly clime Still the surprise sails on

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: Fingers trace a course down the east coast of South Ameri Another, more detailed chart is placed on top of the firs ALLEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This one's by Colnett, Sir. He travelled with Captain Cook and carried a pair of Arnott's chronometers. JACK finds their position and marks it with pencil. A kno on the door. Officers and crew are now dressed according the change in climate KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couple of the men to see you, Sir. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) Show them in. The door opens to reveal NAGEL and WARLEY carrying someth JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this? A scale model of a ship, 15 inches long, perfect in every detail. Jack takes it, delighted, the name picked out in on the stern - Acheron. NAGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It were Warley's idea, Sir. WARLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought she were familiar like, then I remembered where I'd seen her - in Boston, during the Peace. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [   ] In Boston? WARLEY (nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Sir. She's Yankee built. I seen them working on her, something right strange about her scantlings. Then I seen them balls bounce off her an' I got to thinking. NAGEL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you look here, Sir. One side opens up. He pulls a side off the model, exposing its construction. WARLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Nagel here done it just like I seen her - a third layer 'tween the outer and inner ribbing - diagonal bracing, see? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like the U.S. Constitution - our 12 pounders couldn't penetrate except at close range. He passes the model to ALLEN. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killick. Killick, there. KILLICK enters. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An extra ration of rum for these men, from my private store. KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Which I was saving for Saluting Day, Sir. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rouse it up, Killick, and a bottle for Mr. ALLEN and me. Let us live whilst we're alive! KILLICK goes to get the bottles JACK hunkers down to bring his gaze level with the ship, though studying its tiny occupants. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's vulnerable here. He taps the stern windows. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cross her stern, rake her with a broadside through her length. But how to get close enough? Past those long eighteens. That's the devil of it. 136b    SURPRISE QUARTERDECK DAY The Surprise has stopped level with a Spanish merchantman which lies three hundred yards away, headed in the opposi direction. The two boats have hove to and are communicating by megaphone, Stephen translating the Spanish captains words STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says they were chased for three days till they finally our-ran her. Forty gun French privateer headed due south. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Capital. Thank him and let us be off. The Spanish captain, already making sail, waves and shout greeting, which Stephen calls back to him. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say there? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Spanish farewell. "May no new thing arrive." New things being generally by their nature bad.

dialogues.speaker: STEPHEN'S CABIN
dialogues.text: Stephen is with Blakeney, re-bandaging the younger man's stump. Blakeney looks away, his eyes moving over the doct collection of books, learned texts in French Spanish, Gre and Latin BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a manual of exercises sir. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exercises? BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Physical exercises, to make the left arm as powerful as the right once was. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think that will happen with usage, at least to a certain extent. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not completely. I will never be whole again, will I? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No but you will adapt to your new situation The natural world shows us any number of examples of how that is possible. Blakeney bites his lip BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know my father was a great fighting captain. It was always his expectation I would follow in his footsteps. I worry that with this arm I will now be good for nothing but book learning and philosophy. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah. Like me you mean. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (becoming tearful) I cannot use a sextant, cannot tie a knot or climb the rigging. Cannot even dress myself. What chance to I have now of even making first lieutenant. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have every chance. You hear me every chance. Only the other day I heard the captain singing your praises. Your courage, your fortitude in battle, your skill at logarithms and double elevations whatever they may be. And when you are rated lieutenant you shall have someone to tie your bootlaces for you. Aye and help you with your jacket. Here take my handkerchief. I believe we are summonsed to dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MAIN MAST
dialogues.text: The maintop captain, WARLEY, shouts to the deck, his brea forming in the frosty air - WARLEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sail on the larboard bow!

dialogues.speaker: GREAT CABIN/LADDER
dialogues.text: JACK throwing on a heavy boat-cloak, running for the ladd KILLICK behind him trying to get a scarf about JACK's nec and a cap on his head.

dialogues.speaker: THE RIGGING
dialogues.text: Follow JACK as he runs up the ratlines, over the futtock shrouds, then up the topmast shrouds, finally arriving at very top of the mast, to join WARLEY and PULLINGS. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where away? PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hull down, two points off the larboard beam. JACK takes the telescope. 142.   TELESCOPE P.O.V. Just the tips of masts, the hull below the horizon. WARLEY (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's a frigate all right, but no way of knowing if she be the phantom. Beyond the distant ship, a line of black clouds.

dialogues.speaker: RIGGING
dialogues.text: JACK and PULLINGS slide to the deck on parallel back-stay as careless as a couple of midshipmen.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK shouting - JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set studdingsails and top gallants. Then wet the sails and have the idlers placed along the rail. PULLINGS and HOLLAR bark out their orders. Men race to ob JACK steps up on the gunwale, spying out the distant ship BLAKENEY, nearby, rests his telescope on CALAMY's shoulde focussing with his left hand. BLAKENEY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it him, Sir? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch wood, Mr. Blakeney. And I fancy she plans to out-run us. Ask Dr. Maturin to join us, he loves a good chase. BLAKENEY goes below. Above, the topmen release more sail which is tightened by the men on deck hauling on cables. Those not working sit on a row along the windward gunwale like the crew of an ocean racing yacht, to counterbalance pull of the sails.

dialogues.speaker: WEATHER-DECK
dialogues.text: Their speed is so great green seas are now sweeping the forecastle. A man falls and rolls into the scuppers. MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lifelines fore and aft! JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speed, Mr. Calamy? CALAMY heaves the lead and reads the log line, then shout back to JACK - CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twelve knots, Sir!

dialogues.speaker: THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Heeled over under a great press of sail, her copper showi as she clefts the waves.

dialogues.speaker: FORECASTLE
dialogues.text: Lined up along the starboard rails, the crew look back at their captain riding the ship like a charioteer, one eye aloft on the creaking topmost spar. JEMMY DUCKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're cracking on, eh? FASTER DOUDLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll be cracking off presently if he doesn't watch it. SLADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he knows this ship. He knows what she can take. He touches wood, just the same and looks at Joe Plaice wh gives a meaningful roll of his eyes. Ahead, the bank of storm clouds loom gunmetal grey.

dialogues.speaker: GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: PULLINGS knocks and enters, with an anxious looking MR. L with whom he has been arguing a point. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can just see her topsails. She's made her turn westwards. LAMB

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't vouch for the mizzen Sir, not round Cape Horn. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll not lose her now. Set a course westwards. Both men accept this and leave.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK, (TIMELAPSE)
dialogues.text: The wind has increased considerably, the deck sloping lik the roof of a house, the masts bending like coach-whips. PULLINGS and LAMB are looking up at the mizzenmast which making ominous creaks and groans. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Hollar, rig preventer backstays. Warps and light hawsers to the mastheads. JACK stares ahead to the darkening sky as they move acros switchback landscape of massive rolling waves. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get below, Mr. Pullings! PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, Sir? JACK (GRINNING)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better get some food in you. Before it turns nasty.

dialogues.speaker: OCEAN
dialogues.text: Wide to see the two ships. The Surprise and the Acheron w a mile of sea between them. It's like some great ocean ra with neither prepared to take in canvas despite the appal conditions.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: They are running fast before a dangerous, following sea: landscape of hills and valleys, the whole thing in terrif motion. The forecastle now vanishes in foam with every plunge, ri each time with water pouring over the waist and spouting her scuppers. KILLICK comes up with the coffee pot inside his jacket. J drinks from the spout, peering ahead into the murk. A wil unruly part of him is loving this. Above him, more top-men struggle up the rigging, with the mast drawing crazy figure of eights on a rushing sky.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW DECKS
dialogues.text: The dog watch are wolfing their food, mugs and dinner pla sliding over the table. Crewmen walk up hill to the grog barrel, down their ration and head up top again. HIGGINS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You reckon Captain will keep chasing him 'round the Horn with every stitch of canvas flying? DAVIES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I reckon he'd chase him to the gates of hell if he has to. PLAICE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's where we're all going if he doesn't take in sail. Since his injury, Joe Plaice's startlingly random pronouncements have acquired the quality of an oracle.

dialogues.speaker: ON DECK
dialogues.text: The wind rising from yell to shriek. Waves blown flat by the ship travelling at a drunken sideways angle across a raging expanse of white foam. Four men on the wheel, lashed to it, with the air around full of water. In the distance a tower of black rock on the rim of the s distant rollers breaking against it and surging up to a preposterous height. JACK looks up at the great press of canvas as he paces th quarterdeck, the officers glancing from the sails back to JACK. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Strike the topgallants. Men gratefully rush to the ratlines and begin climbing to masts. STEPHEN staggers up onto deck. JACK calls to him, pointin the black rock. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cape Horn, Doctor! STEPHEN stares across at the legendary Cape. He's struggl with his pocket-glass when a lurch of the ship sends him tumbling. As men help him below, WARLEY, the maintop capt reports to the bosun. HOLLAR (to WARLEY)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help them with that mizzen topgallant! You go too, Mr. Hollom! HOLLOM looks desperate as he follows WARLEY up the ratlin of the mizzen. 154.   MIZZEN TOPgallant MAST WARLEY works frantically. He's out on the yardarm high ab the raging sea. He shouts for HOLLOM to join him, but HOL is still in the top, some twenty feet below, unable or unwilling to climb any higher.

dialogues.speaker: THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Wide to see the ship. WARLEY working on the swaying mizze The bow swinging a couple of points further south.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: Wood and rope straining as they wrestle to turn. Then a tremendous crack as the mizzen-topmast splits and flies backward into the sea, carrying WARLEY along with it. BONDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man overboard! Sail and cordage falling over the men at the wheel. A loo block and tackle swinging murderously in the gale. JACK fights free from the tangle of ropes as WARLEY vanis in the foam. The mizzenmast is acting as a sea-anchor dragging the ship's head northwards toward the black rock JACK grabs a speaking-trumpet as WARLEY briefly reappears JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Swim for the wreckage, man! Then to PULLINGS. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reduce sail! As crewmen scramble frantically into the rigging, JACK tu back to see WARLEY desperately swimming toward the traili wreckage, his mates shouting encouragement over the howli wind. With sails reduced the ship perceptibly slows, but the dragging wreckage is swinging the ship broadside on to th waves. BONDEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's broaching! PULLINGS runs to JACK, pointing to the trailing mass of r and mast. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's acting as a sea-anchor! We must cut it loose, Sir! WARLEY still struggling to reach the wreckage but going u with each wave. JACK, agonized, makes his decision. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Axes! AWKWARD DAVIES scrambles up the ladder with an axe, but l his footing and falls sprawling over the quarterdeck. JACK grabs the axe and attacks the ropes. He's joined by NAGEL who has run to assist before realizing that the man overboard is his friend Warley. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Set to then. Set to!! NAGEL's face is a mask of horror, but he obeys Jacks orde and starts chopping. He and Jack work shoulder to shoulde matching blow for blow [   ] The prow keeps turning, wave after wave coming at right angles to the ship.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GUN-DECK
dialogues.text: A hatch cover is torn off by the force of water, a sudden mighty deluge pouring down into the lower levels drenchin the men and swamping the guns. HOLLAR (yells below)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All hands to the pumps!

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK and NAGEL [   ] keep hacking at the tangle of ropes. Knocking chips off the railing in their urgency to cut fr the dragging mast. Finally they succeed. The last of the ropes [ ] whips awa the broken mizzen disappears aft and the ship swings southward, away from the rocks. The wreckage is swept away by the next wave, leaving WARL struggling, his last chance of getting back to the ship g Then another wave breaks over him and he is gone. NAGEL is bereft. JACK lowers his head.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: KILLICK and BLACK BILL. KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's been at it again. BLACK BILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that then? KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Jonah. BLACK BILL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Jonah?

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: JACK sits at his desk. The model of the Acheron that WARL helped make sits accusingly in front of him. STEPHEN pours him a glass on wine, and one for himself. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The deaths in actual battle are the easiest. (beat) For my own part - those who die under the knife or from some consequent infection: I have to remind myself that it is the enemy who killed them, and not me. (beat) Warley was a casualty of war, as surely as if a French ball had taken him. JACK nods. Obviously the death still weighs on his conscience. [ ] STEPHEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (offering the wine) At the same time.... He breaks off Jack

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the same time, what? Stephen hesitates, aware that he has to proceed carefully STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that I wear two hats on every voyage. I am the captains particular friend and supporter, but also I am the ships doctor in which later capacity I am party to.... He catches a steely glint in Jacks eye and breaks off. STEPHEN (CONT'D) You don't want me to continue. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stiffly) On the contrary. I insist on it. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is talk below decks of turning back. Or rather that we should have turned back some weeks ago. Of course the men would follow "Lucky Jack" anywhere, and usually in the confident expectation of victory. But that of course is the problem. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is the problem? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That you are not accustomed to defeat Jack. That you have taken it too personally. That chasing this larger, faster ship, with its long guns, is beginning to smack of pride 'which goeth before destruction'? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not pride nor anything like it, it's a question of duty. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Duty', ah yes. The naval signal for end of discussion. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can be as 'satiric' as you like, Stephen, but I have my orders. She is attacking our whalers. For why? Without whales we have no boot polish, nor any soap, nor oil for our lamps, not to oil our sabres and muskets. Destroying our whalers could win the war for Napoleon. Which is why we must catch this Acheron. As a man of learning surely you can see that. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At whatever the cost? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any whatever cost I choose to pay. And I will calculate that myself, Stephen without reference to your friends in the ward room.

dialogues.speaker: 160A MIZZEN-TOP
dialogues.text: An icy wind whips at the men working on the temporary miz mast. Hollom, half way up the rigging is relaying instructions between the men in the rigging and the men on deck HOLLOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cast off. The new yard flails around on its pulley, bashing dangero against the mast. Almost claiming Nagel HOLLOM (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belay. Sorry. Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: PULLING craning upwards. The topmen's shouted commands ar whipped away by the gale. JACK joins him, still smarting from the conversation with Stephen JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to go further south, get around this bloody west wind. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How far south? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As far as is necessary, Mr. Pullings. The sixtieth parallel if need be.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Tacking southwards. The sun, a pale anaemic disc, gradual disappearing behind layers of cloud. The wind is a constant shrill whistle through the rigging sound like some infernal drill which rises and falls but never ceases.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: The sun rising in a clear sky which turns a sapphire blue White ice-islands lie all around them, some a pure, rosy pink. Others bright ultramarine. And still the wind howls, driving them further south. MOWETT passes his telescope to STEPHEN MATURIN. As STEPHE studies some seals on an ice-beach, MOWETT launches into verse, shouting against the wind - MOWETT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we upon the globes last verge shall go to view the ocean leaning on the sky from thence our rolling neighbours we shall know and on the hidden world securely pry! He is interrupted by a bundle of guns clattering on board from one of the small boats. They are followed by Mr Howa clad in several thicknesses of sealskin and carrying a br of dead penguin.

dialogues.speaker: THE SHIP AT NIGHT
dialogues.text: The ship scudding onwards, soundless at this distance, bu for the chilling high pitched whistle of the wind. An iceberg passes in foreground, fantastic shapes of ice, like a Gothic cathedral, sculpted by the elements.

dialogues.speaker: BERTH DECK
dialogues.text: Hanging stoves provide some feeble warmth. Men huddle clo to them, their breath condensing, or lie shivering in the bunks, unable to sleep for the cold. HOLLAR appears with a lantern. HOLLAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise and shine! Show a leg there, tumble up, tumble up - sleepers awake! As the previous watch arrive downstairs, numb and dazed f the cold, the next watch emerge from their hammocks and dress. No-one speaks.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: The officers take their places at dinner. Once again it's penguin stew. PULLINGS comes in, with an unexpected smile on his face a whispers something to JACK. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praise be. At last. The others seem to know what's going on, all except STEPH who looks baffled. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pray what is there to celebrate? JACK holds up his hand for silence. A series of creaks an groans from the ship. The coffee pot tilts on its gimbals JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have made our turn northward, Doctor. We are headed back toward the sun... The officers give a slightly ragged cheer. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...in anticipation of which. I asked Killick to prepare something special. (shouts off) Killick. Killick there. KILLICK comes in with his usual exasperated expression, bearing a tray with a silver tureen lid on it. KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which I was just coming. He lays it on the table. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, I give you... our destination. He whips off the lid to reveal a strange glutinous mass, pudding cut in the oddest of shapes. Everyone stands to g better look. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Galapagos Islands. PULLINGS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Pon my word so it is. Look: here's Narborough, Chatham and Hood... JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where the whalers are, ain't it Mr Allen. So that's where the Acheron will be headed. The mood is now taken over by the glee of recognition, as officers marvel over the pudding. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Pullings, if you'll permit me, a slice of Albermale. For you Doctor, Redondo Rock. There's a tiny man-of-war made of icing, between the isla JACK picks it up in his spoon. JACK (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, with a fair wind behind us the Acheron for me.

dialogues.speaker: OPEN OCEAN, DOLDRUMS
dialogues.text: Slow pan over a glassy expanse of water. JACK's head sudd breaks the surface, close to camera. As he swims he brings the Surprise into view. The ship is utterly becalmed, wallowing in the swell, her sails hangi limp. A 'painted ship upon a painted ocean'. JACK swims around the ship, which currently presents a le than warlike picture with washing hanging from every part the rigging. He calls up to PULLINGS - JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Best bowers chipped... Lot of rust on these forechains... black strake needs another coat.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK
dialogues.text: JACK comes aboard, takes a towel from KILLICK and looks a him. The men are holystoning the deck and polishing the brightwork. They look thin and exhausted and burnt dark-b by the sun and wind.

dialogues.speaker: FORECASTLE
