dialogues.speaker: IN THE SICK-BERTH, ACHERON
dialogues.text: A doctor is working here, a callow-faced man in a bloody apron, red-eyed from fatigue. JACK enters, a fearsome sight, with his singed yellow hai and blood-stained cutlass. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Le Capitaine? Where is he? The doctor points at a body on the operating table. JACK approaches, looks down at the dead man. He's [ ] somewhere about JACK's age, fine-featured, with his black coat draped over his body. DOCTOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Il mГЎvait prie de vous donner ceci. Passing JACK the captain's sword.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK, ACHERON
dialogues.text: JACK picks his way through the dead and wounded to where CALAMY sits nursing BLAKENEY. CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dead, sir. Gently, JACK picks up the lifeless body and walks slowly down the quarterdeck, the boy draped across his arms. Friend and foe part silently in front of him as he crosse the gangway to...

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK, SURPRISE
dialogues.text: ...then with CALAMY following, he goes below.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: JACK in wide shot, sitting alone on the bench running und the stern windows. His hunched posture and red tear-stain eyes give a glimpse of his familiar post-battle mood - a of grief and depression, the old question, "Was it worth price?".

dialogues.speaker: ACHERON AND SURPRISE
dialogues.text: The two ships anchored close together on the ocean.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK, SURPRISE
dialogues.text: As eight bells are rung for the change of watch we see a of canvas hammocks each containing the body of a fallen crewman. DAVIES and PLAICE stitch the bodies into their hammocks, BLAKENEY the last body in the line. As the men approach - CALAMY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do it. JOE passes him the needle and twine, then they leave him alone. As CALAMY sews up the hammock, HOLLAR's voice is heard distinctly from below. HOLLAR (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rise and shine, show a leg there. Tumble up! Tumble up! In close-up: the peaceful face of BLAKENEY HOLLAR (O.S.) (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleepers awake! ...as CALAMY's hands stitch the canvas closed.

dialogues.speaker: THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: The small figures of the crew assembled on the quarterdec JACK's voice drifting across the water. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: John Henry ALLEN... Joseph NAGEL... William Horner... Stephen Winston Boyle... and Lieutenant William Blakeney We therefore commit their bodies to the deep, looking for the resurrection of the body, when the sea shall give up her dead... Amen. ALL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amen. The bodies in their weighted hammocks slide into the sea.

dialogues.speaker: BOW OF THE SURPRISE
dialogues.text: Wide on STEPHEN and BLAKENEY as they sit watching two dolphins surfing the bow-wave, STEPHEN pointing out vario features of these magnificent creatures, doing his best t take the boy's mind off the loss of his friend.

dialogues.speaker: THE SURPRISE AND THE ACHERON
dialogues.text: The two ships sail abreast - the Acheron, her shattered m jury-rigged.

dialogues.speaker: QUARTERDECK, SURPRISE
dialogues.text: JACK stands with LIEUTENANT MOWETT and the signals midshipman, WILLIAMSON. They look across at the Acheron. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Signal... 'Parole prisoners Valparaiso'... WILLIAMSON

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean Lieutenant Pullings, Sir? JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Captain Pullings. WILLIAMSON hurries to the signals locker, the signal book JACK's message in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The line of colored signal-flags run up to the mast-head the Surprise.

dialogues.speaker: 309A QUARTERDECK ACHERON
dialogues.text: Midshipman Rye is reading the signal for Pullings RYE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....then 'Rendezvous Portsmouth. God- speed, Captain Pullings.' A contented smile on Pullings face as his promotion is confirmed. He waves across to JACK as the Acheron makes a sharp turn away from the Surprise.

dialogues.speaker: ABOUT THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Slowly the crew come back to life as old familiar habits routines reassert themselves. В· Acting First Lieutenant MOWETT walks the quarterdeck composing a poem in memory of the battle. В· JOE PLAICE tells a story of witchcraft and haunted shi a small attentive audience. В· While AWKWARD DAVIES works further on the tattoo about BECKETT's waist. The chain begun off BRAZIL now winds its around most of his torso. В· BLAKENEY and JEMMY DUCKS are feeding the assorted crea collected at the Galapagos, as... В· BONDEN reads his first book, 'Diseases of Seamen' by Stephen Maturin, his brow furrowed, his lips moving silen В· While the powder-monkeys skylark in the rigging

dialogues.speaker: INTERIOR, GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: STEPHEN plays a note on his cello [      ] STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we begin? JACK pauses, gazing into space. STEPHEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack, brother, you're gathering wool. JACK (smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thinking about their captain. A great seaman, whatever you may say of him. The doctor said he was killed by our first broadside. I'd have liked to talk to him, face to face. STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you did. JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? STEPHEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While I was tending the prisoners they told me their doctor died of fever, two weeks ago. There was no doctor on that ship when we boarded it. And I doubt you will find one there now. JACK goes very still. A silence broken only by the sound water flowing gently past the hull. He looks down at the captain's sword on the table, the thought of a possible final deception flooding through hi STEPHEN (CONT'D)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall we? He starts to play, the deep booming sound of the cello carrying through to ....

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE GREAT CABIN
dialogues.text: KILLICK, wearing an ostentatious bandage about his head, preparing toasted cheese with BLACK BILL. KILLICK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the last of the cheese and like as not they'll leave it seizing to their plates with their tweedly tweedly tweedly. JACK (O.S.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Killick? KILLICK THERE! KILLICK (projecting)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which it will be ready when it's ready! In the cabin, the violin joins with the cello. Rolling, undeniable music, the music of the waves, resonating thro the great ship and filling the night. Stephens mind is fa away. Jack breaks off abruptly: JACK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're still missing your cormorant... flightless eh...well then. It will still be there when we come back And he breaks into a merry jig

dialogues.speaker: SURPRISE, EXTERIOR
dialogues.text: Wide, to see the stern of the ship and a patch of surroun water lit by the great stern lantern. Through the casemen windows the two men can be seen playing. Wider, to the vast dark sky and the heaving ocean all aro with the stern cabin, a tiny orange light, still faintly visible in the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: FURTHER BACK
dialogues.text: And further still. Until we see the curve of the earth, a the planet spinning on its journey through space.
